guide.conclusion: Obviously, one should use caution when hanging heavy, valuable, or fragile items, but you will probably be surprised at how strong these hangers are.
guide.introduction: Shown here is a simple method for A) removing a stay tab from a soda can with the rivet-ring intact, and B) attaching the tab to a wooden frame or board using the rivet ring. The pull-ring is then conveniently used for hanging from a nail.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Shown here is a simple method for A) removing a stay tab from a soda can with the rivet-ring intact, and B) attaching the tab to a wooden frame or board using the rivet ring. The pull-ring is then conveniently used for hanging from a nail.

Relevant parts
  • Soda can
  • Screw
Tools
  • Pliers
  • Screwdriver

parts.notes: to fit rivet hole in tab

lines.text: Rotate the tab around the rivet until the pull ring is directly over the open mouth of the can.
lines.text_raw: Rotate the tab around the rivet until the pull ring is directly over the open mouth of the can.

lines.text: Grasp the short end of the tab with a pair of pliers, as shown.
lines.text_raw: Grasp the short end of the tab with a pair of pliers, as shown.

lines.text: Bend the tab down into the mouth of the can while pulling up at the same time.
lines.text_raw: Bend the tab down into the mouth of the can while pulling up at the same time.

lines.text: The tab should pop neatly off the rivet with the ring intact.
lines.text_raw: The tab should pop neatly off the rivet with the ring intact.

lines.text: Mark a convenient centered location in the upper back surface of the piece to be hung.
lines.text_raw: Mark a convenient centered location in the upper back surface of the piece to be hung.

lines.text: Set the tab in position with the rivet hole over the mark.
lines.text_raw: Set the tab in position with the rivet hole over the mark.

lines.text: Drive a short wood screw through the tab's rivet hole into the marked location.
lines.text_raw: Drive a short wood screw through the tab's rivet hole into the marked location.

lines.text: If your piece is softwood, like pine, a pilot hole is probably not necessary.  If it's hardwood, you may want to drill a very small pilot hole first.
lines.text_raw: If your piece is softwood, like pine, a pilot hole is probably not necessary.  If it's hardwood, you may want to drill a very small pilot hole first.

lines.text: You may find that the pull ring on the mounted tab does not have sufficient clearance from the wood to go over a nail head.
lines.text_raw: You may find that the pull ring on the mounted tab does not have sufficient clearance from the wood to go over a nail head.

lines.text: If so, insert a flat-blade screwdriver under the pull ring, as shown, and gently pry it out away from the wood.
lines.text_raw: If so, insert a flat-blade screwdriver under the pull ring, as shown, and gently pry it out away from the wood.

lines.text: Drive a small nail in the wall where you want the picture to hang.  A slight downward angle is best.
lines.text_raw: Drive a small nail in the wall where you want the picture to hang.  A slight downward angle is best.

lines.text: Slip the pull ring over the nail head.
lines.text_raw: Slip the pull ring over the nail head.

lines.text: Straighten the picture, and you're done.
lines.text_raw: Straighten the picture, and you're done.

lines.text: (And yes, before anyone asks, we know the inscription on the back is upside-down.  Mom was very upset with herself.)

guide.summary: Quick, easy, free trick for hanging lightweight items.
